author: fradamt
content:
The whole crList thing is in combination with PBS, which comes with (block, slot) attestations, meaning you can vote against block B at slot n by voting for its parent A from slot n-1, but at slot n (e.g. attest to (A, n) instead of (B,n)).  What that means then is that a builder at slot 2n+3 which does not comply with the crList from the previous proposer (the one from slot 2n) can have their block voted out of the fork-choice. 
The reason to have the list be made by the previous proposer (rather than the one from 2n+2, I.e. the one which has chosen this builder) is that this way there is 0 reason to not make a crList or to be careful about what you put in it, at least in terms of profits (of course you might be worried  about legal repercussions of making a certain kind of list, but we can‚Äôt do anything to prevent that)

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, I see.  So "vote **against**" here means to vote for a *different* block to be in that slot.  I didn't realize that was planning to be an option.  Thanks!

author: fradamt
content: Yes. Currently it‚Äôs not an option because voting for the parent A of block B also contributes fork-choice weight to B (B always dominates A in the fork-choice), so you can‚Äôt vote for excluding something from the chain

author: fradamt
content: Generally, this allows any kind of ‚Äúcommittee-enforceable property‚Äù, meaning attempting to use ‚Äúvoting against‚Äù to enforce things which cannot be done with validity conditions (e.g. timing requirements)
